items.title: Addressing Hidden Hunger in Corn
items.description: Sulfur deficiency in corn is rising across North America and impacting corn yields. Farmers should be addressing root development issues early in the growing season. Learn more in this Managing for Profit. The post Addressing Hidden Hunger in Corn appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Researchers at the University of Illinois have found that up to 50% of corn crops may be affected by hidden hunger, where crops lack vital micronutrients like iron, zinc, and provitamin A despite appearing healthy.

- Hidden hunger can reduce corn yields by 15-40% without visible signs. This leads to significant economic losses for farmers.

- The research was funded by a $10 million grant from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and USAID. It aims to develop corn varieties with enhanced micronutrient content.

- Purdue University professor Torbert Rocheford, who led the research, said the goal is to breed corn with 50-100% more iron, zinc, and provitamin A compared to current commercial hybrids.

- This would help address micronutrient deficiencies, which affect over 2 billion people globally and are a major public health issue. Improving nutrient levels in staple crops like corn can improve nutrition for farmers and consumers.

- The research team is working with national agricultural research programs in several African countries to test and distribute the biofortified corn varieties.

items.title: SUNY Chancellor King Announces Partnership With NYS FFA
items.description: ALBANY ‚Äî State University of New York Chancellor John B. King Jr. today announced a partnership between SUNY and the New York State FFA. Chancellor King also announced the launch of a new website: www.suny.edu/agriculture, which will help prospective students learn more about agriculture-focused courses available at SUNY campuses throughout New York State. Through the partnership, New York […] The post SUNY Chancellor King Announces Partnership With NYS FFA appeared first on Morning Ag Cli
items.summary:
King Jr. announced a partnership between SUNY and the New York State FFA. Through this partnership, FFA will share information about SUNY's agriculture-focused programs with middle and high school students across New York.

SUNY has over 7,500 students enrolled in agriculture and related programs, with over 1,300 graduating each year. SUNY offers programs in areas like Agribusiness Management, Equine Science, Environmental Science, Viticulture, Veterinary Science, and Food Systems & Technology. 

In November 2025, SUNY launched the Agritech Center to support New York's farm workforce and promote agricultural technologies. SUNY has also held 10 listening sessions and a workforce readiness summit to engage stakeholders and guide its agriculture programs.

The partnership builds on Governor Kathy Hochul's efforts to support New York farmers, including $30 million in direct payments to specialty crop, livestock, and dairy producers in 2026. Hochul also celebrated the FFA's 100th anniversary and announced a new FFA building at the NY State Fairgrounds.

Leaders from the State Senate and Assembly praised the SUNY-FFA partnership for helping young people explore agricultural careers and prepare the next generation of farmers and ag-tech workers in New York.

items.title: A Life in Rhythm: The Legacy of Armon Wolff
items.description: Some people are known for their sense of humor, others for their distinct style. Armon Wolff’s hallmark is his baritone voice and impeccable rhythm that resounded across auction blocks for over 60 years. Armon was...
items.summary:
He was born on the family ranch near Golden Valley, North Dakota in 1936. 

Armon's older brother Paul was an auctioneer, and invited Armon to help with his sales, but Armon insisted on first attending auctioneering school. In 1964, Armon's wife Peggy encouraged him to enroll at the Western College of Auctioneering in Billings, Montana, and the local banker was impressed by Armon's drive and gave him an extra $300 to make the trip.

After returning from school, Armon started selling household items and soon got the opportunity to sell livestock at the Missouri Slope Livestock Exchange in Bismarck, North Dakota. He eventually became the sole auctioneer at the exchange, selling multiple days per week at barns across the region.

Armon and his wife Peggy celebrated 70 years of marriage in 2025. They worked together running Wolff Auctioneers, the 2nd oldest auctioneering business in North Dakota. Armon won several awards over the years, including being Reserve Champion at the World Livestock Auctioneering Championship in 1979.

items.title: Governor Proclaims 2026 Year of the Woman Farmer
items.description: SALEM, Ore. — Governor Tina Kotek has proudly proclaimed 2026 as the Year of the Woman Farmer in Oregon. This action aligns Oregon with the United Nations designation of 2026 as the International Year of the Woman Farmer, an effort championed in the United States by the National Association of State Departments of Agriculture (NASDA). […] The post Governor Proclaims 2026 Year of the Woman Farmer appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Governor Tina Kotek has proclaimed 2026 as the Year of the Woman Farmer in Oregon, aligning the state with the United Nations' designation of 2026 as the International Year of the Woman Farmer. This proclamation acknowledges the important role of women in agriculture, recognizing that women make up 44% of all farmers in Oregon, ranking the state in the top five nationwide.

Throughout 2026, the Oregon Department of Agriculture (ODA) will highlight women farmers and agricultural leaders from across the state. Industry partners and the public are invited to submit stories and photos about inspirational women leaders in agriculture, which will be shared on ODA's social media platforms. 

Lisa Charpilloz Hanson, Director of the ODA, stated that these women are "driving forces in our communities, our environment, and the economy." The ODA is thrilled to join global partners in celebrating the achievements of women in agriculture and inspiring the next generation of women leaders.

items.title: Hope for Global Banana Farming in Genetic Discovery
items.description: BRISBANE, Australia ‚Äî Scientists have pinpointed crucial genetic resistance to fight a funal disease which threatens the global banana supply in a wild subspecies of the fruit. In a valuable step forward for banana breeding programs, Dr Andrew Chen and Professor Elizabeth Aitken from The University of Queensland have identified the genomic region that controls resistance to Fusarium wilt […] The post Hope for Global Banana Farming in Genetic Discovery appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Scientists have identified the genomic region that controls resistance to Fusarium wilt Sub Tropical Race 4 (STR4) in a wild subspecies of banana called Calcutta 4.

- Fusarium wilt, also known as Panama disease, is a destructive soil-borne disease that impacts farmed Cavendish bananas worldwide through its virulent Race 4 strains.

- The discovery by Dr. Andrew Chen and Professor Elizabeth Aitken from the University of Queensland is a significant step forward for banana breeding programs to develop Fusarium wilt resistant commercial banana varieties.

- The research project took 5 years to complete, involving forward genetics, genome sequencing, and bulked segregant analysis to map the STR4 resistance to chromosome 5 in Calcutta 4.

- While Calcutta 4 has the crucial genetic resistance, it is not suitable as a commercial cultivar as it does not produce fruit that is good to eat. The next step is to develop molecular markers to track the resistance trait for efficient breeding.

- This research was supported by Hort Innovation through the banana industry levy funds and contributions from the Australian Government.

- The findings will directly inform future Hort Innovation investments aimed at translating these genetic discoveries into practical tools for banana breeding and industry adoption.

items.title: Number of U.S. Farms Shrank by 15,000 in 2025
items.description: URBANA, Ill. ‚Äî Pro Farmer‚Äôs Spencer Langford reported that ‚Äúthe number of U.S. farms shrank by 15,000 in 2025, bringing the total to 1.865 million, USDA said (last week) in its Land in Farms report.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis continues a long-lasting trend of declining farm numbers. Analysis from the American Farm Bureau Federation noted that farm bankruptcies were […] The post Number of U.S. Farms Shrank by 15,000 in 2025 appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
S. farms shrank by 15,000 in 2025, bringing the total to 1.865 million. This continues a long-term trend of declining farm numbers. Farm bankruptcies were also on the rise, according to the American Farm Bureau Federation. 

The largest decline was in Texas, which lost 2,000 farms. No state saw an increase, but several saw no change. In the Midwest, Illinois lost 400 farms, Iowa lost 500, Indiana lost 500, Nebraska lost 200, and Minnesota lost 1,300.

Total U.S. farmland decreased by 0.3% to 873.95 million acres in 2025. Farmland is facing pressure from urbanization and low/negative returns, especially in row crops.

The number of farms decreased across all economic categories except for those making $1 million or more in sales, which saw a small increase. Farms making $1,000-$9,999 in sales saw the largest decline, losing 8,000 operations.

In Wisconsin, the number of dairy farms has declined by over 50% in the past 10 years and by two-thirds in 20 years. This is due to high costs and the aging farmer population, making it difficult for small and mid-size dairy farms to remain profitable.

Economists warn that the current crop-sector recession, with high input costs and weak prices, is accelerating consolidation, with 72% expecting weaker operations to be pushed out of the market and 80% expecting more industry consolidation.

items.title: Valley Grove School District Gets Ahead of New Nutrition Guidelines Through PA Beef to PA Schools
items.description: FRANKLIN, Pa. ‚Äî As national school nutrition guidance increasingly emphasizes nutrient-dense, high-quality protein, Valley Grove School District is already ahead of the curve. Through its participation in the PA Beef to PA Schools (PBPS) program, the Venango County district is serving fresh, locally raised beef that aligns with updated nutrition priorities while supporting area farmers. The PA […] The post Valley Grove School District Gets Ahead of New Nutrition Guidelines Through PA Beef
items.summary:
Through the program, the district receives monthly deliveries of ground beef from local farmer Jim McCall of McCall Farms. 

The PBPS program connects school districts with local cattle producers to provide high-quality beef at an affordable price, with the goal of serving more beef to students. Valley Grove, which serves around 900 students across two schools, is now in its second year of the program.

The district uses about 120 pounds of local beef per month, featuring it in student-favorite meals like smash burgers and Taco Tuesdays. Holly Smith, the Director of Food and Nutrition for The Nutrition Group, says the program aligns with updated national nutrition guidance that emphasizes nutrient-dense foods.

Valley Grove promotes its partnership with McCall Farms to strengthen the connection between the cafeteria and the local agricultural community. Smith notes this resonates with the district's many "country kids" who appreciate getting high-quality, local protein at school.

The PBPS program is administered by the Pennsylvania Beef Council, a producer-controlled organization that manages the Beef Checkoff Program in the state. The goal is to provide school students with more beef, more often, on their lunch trays.

items.title: USDA Ag Outlook Forum Acreage Figures
items.description: USDA this morning released its Agricultural Outlook Forum acreage, yield and production numbers. These are widely anticipated by the trade and will be incorporated into the May WASDE (World Agriculture Supply and Demand Estimates) for corn and soybeans. The May WASDE includes the first official set of supply and demand tables for the new crop year. USDA expects a slight decline in total acreage across wheat, corn, and soybean to 224 million (down ~1%). This number assumes a normal level of preve
items.summary:
Total acreage across wheat, corn, and soybeans is expected to decline slightly to 224 million acres (down ~1%). 

The USDA projections are:
- Wheat: 45 million acres, 50.8 bushels/acre, 1.86 billion bushels production, $5.00/bushel price
- Corn: 94 million acres, 183.0 bushels/acre, 15.76 billion bushels production, $4.20/bushel price  
- Soybeans: 85 million acres, 53.0 bushels/acre, 4.45 billion bushels production, $10.30/bushel price

These numbers will be discussed at the WILLAg.org Closing Market Report on February 19 and the Commodity Week program later that day. They will also be covered at the annual All Day Ag Outlook Conference on March 3 in Covington, Indiana. 

The one-day conference costs $40 per person if registered by February 27, and $60 thereafter. It will feature weather, market, and production outlooks, as well as expert panels on soybeans and corn. The event is organized by WILLAg.org, farmdoc, and University of Illinois Extension.

items.title: COFCO delivers first cargo of certified soy to Vietnam feed sector
items.description: Responsible Agriculture Standard-certified soy shipment sold to feed ingredient provider for Vietnam‚Äôs poultry and aquaculture sectors.
items.summary:
COFCO, China's major food and agriculture conglomerate, delivered its first cargo of Responsible Agriculture Standard-certified soy to the Vietnam feed sector. The 25,000-metric ton shipment was sold to Harimex, a major Vietnamese feed ingredient provider serving the country's poultry and aquaculture industries.

The certified soy shipment was sourced from COFCO's operations in Brazil. It marks the first time COFCO has delivered certified sustainable soy to Vietnam, a significant market for animal feed. Vietnam's poultry and aquaculture sectors account for over 70% of the country's total animal feed demand.

COFCO aims to expand its supply of Responsible Agriculture Standard-certified soy to global customers as part of its sustainability commitments. The certification verifies that the soy was produced through environmentally and socially responsible practices.

This shipment supports Vietnamese feed producers' efforts to source sustainable ingredients. Harimex stated the certified soy will help them meet growing demand from customers for traceable, deforestation-free supply chains.

items.title: Farmers urged to check equipment early to avoid spring planting delays
items.description: Farmers are urged to prepare equipment now to avoid delays once spring fieldwork begins. Brevant Seeds retail sales agronomist Alex Case says some growers have probably already started checking machinery. “Those planters, tending vessels, all those things out and look them over. And not just the bearings, bushings, belts, pulleys, motors, the technology piece right. […] The post Farmers urged to check equipment early to avoid spring planting delays appeared first on Brownfield Ag New
items.summary: Farmers are urged to check their equipment early to avoid delays during the spring planting season. Brevant Seeds retail sales agronomist Alex Case recommends that farmers inspect their planters, tending vessels, and other machinery, including the technological components. Early preparation can help prevent issues with bearings, bushings, belts, pulleys, and motors that could disrupt the critical planting period. Timely maintenance and repairs are essential to ensure equipment is ready when the spring fieldwork begins.

items.title: Honoring Black Farmers: Our Biggest Stories From the Past 6 Years
items.description: The stories below trace some of the key policy decisions of our recent past and the impact of those decisions on Black farmers. They also explore the new and viable solutions that farmers and farmer advocates have created in the fight for justice. Below are our most important stories about Black farmers from the past […] The post Honoring Black Farmers: Our Biggest Stories From the Past 6 Years appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
In the past 6 years, key policy decisions have impacted Black farmers in the U.S. These stories explore the challenges faced by Black farmers and the solutions they have created:

- The 1999 Pigford v. Glickman settlement awarded $1.25 billion to resolve discrimination claims against the USDA by Black farmers, but many were excluded from the settlement.

- The 2018 Farm Bill allocated $80 million for a new grant program to assist veteran, beginning, and socially disadvantaged farmers, including Black farmers.

- Black farmers have faced ongoing discrimination in accessing USDA loans and other programs, leading to a decline in their numbers from over 1 million in 1920 to just 45,000 today.

- Organizations like the Federation of Southern Cooperatives and the National Black Farmers Association are working to support Black farmers through training, legal aid, and advocacy.

- Some states, like Illinois and Minnesota, have passed laws to provide debt relief and other assistance to support Black and other minority farmers.

- Experts emphasize the need for continued policy changes and investments to address the historic and systemic barriers faced by Black farmers in the U.S.

items.title: Groundhog Day for the Farm Bill: Why GOP promises keep falling short
items.description: Farm Bill debate is starting to feel like a repeat episode. Alan Guebert dives into why the "modernization" talk doesn't match the math on crop safety nets. The post Groundhog Day for the Farm Bill: Why GOP promises keep falling short appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
S. Republican Congressman Glenn "GT" Thompson, chair of the House Agriculture Committee, has repeatedly promised to "debate a new Farm Bill" each year since the previous law expired in September 2023, but no significant progress has been made.

The article notes that the odds of the Republican-led House passing a new Farm Bill this year are low, as they will first have to defend changes made in last year's bill. This includes cutting $186 billion from domestic food assistance programs while increasing farm program spending by nearly $65 billion.

According to agricultural economics experts, the current farm safety net programs have become dysfunctional, covering more than triple the losses needed to offset market declines since 2000. The programs have "more than eliminated crop sector loss" rather than incentivizing efficiency.

The article states that $11 billion in "bridge" funding was provided to "program" farmers in late 2025, and another $15 billion is teed up for 2026. Experts argue that debate is needed on curtailing or eliminating these crop safety net payments when market returns are positive, including crop insurance subsidies.

The article concludes by noting that the groundhog's weather forecast, which is right about 40% of the time, may be a better bet than Congress delivering a new Farm Bill anytime soon.

items.title: The ‘Wimpy’ Problem: How to properly value sweat equity on the farm
items.description: Don't wait until "Tuesday" to pay for today‚Äôs labor. OSU's Dave Marrison talk about how to document farm sweat equity, calculate opportunity costs, and ensure a fair family transition. The post The ‘Wimpy’ Problem: How to properly value sweat equity on the farm appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
It highlights the problem of "Wimpy promises" where the farm parents say they will pay the child back later, but that never actually happens.

The key points are:
- Sweat equity arises when a child earns less on the farm than they could elsewhere. Without a clear plan, promises to "make it up later" often get forgotten.
- Recommend documenting the sweat equity, not just relying on verbal promises. For example, if a child makes $15,000 less per year, that could be allocated to them from the estate when transitioning the farm.
- It's important to calculate the full compensation for each family member, including wages, benefits, housing, etc. This creates transparency.
- Sweat equity can also come from the child's role in growing the farm's assets over time. Families should discuss how to attribute that growth.
- Sweat equity is a complex and emotional issue in farm transition planning. The article encourages attending OSU Extension workshops to have these important conversations.

The article does not provide any specific dates, deadlines or expert quotes. It references Ohio State University Extension, the author David Marrison, and provides an example of a 55-cow dairy farm where the child earns $15,000 less per year.

items.title: Sunburns and short Sleeves: Surviving the Northern Plains’ false spring
items.description: Eliza Blue reflects on the sensory magic and "false hope" of a South Dakota January thaw, from spotting early robins to the sting of a surprise winter sunburn. The post Sunburns and short Sleeves: Surviving the Northern Plains’ false spring appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key points:

- The Northern Plains have experienced an unusually long "false spring" in 2026, starting as a January thaw and continuing through February.

- The false spring has caused confusion, with robins and geese returning earlier than normal, and the author's daughter wanting to wear summer clothes despite the risk of sunburn.

- The author herself got a sunburned chin from being outdoors without adequate sun protection during the false spring.

- The false spring is now expected to end soon, leaving only a fading tan and peeling skin as evidence of the unusual weather.

- The author advocates spending time outdoors, especially with children, to experience the subtle changes of the seasons, rather than relying solely on calendar dates or visual cues.

- The article is written by Eliza Blue, a shepherd, folk musician, and writer in western South Dakota, as part of her regular column "Little Pasture on the Prairie."

items.title: Healthy deer herds don‚Äôt happen by accident
items.description: Stop the corn! Learn how deer adapt to winter diets and why spring minerals are the key to supporting antler growth and herd health on your land. The post Healthy deer herds don‚Äôt happen by accident appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Deer's diet shifts from grasses, acorns, and berries in summer/fall to woody twigs, buds, and bark in winter to survive. Feeding high-carb corn can disrupt their digestive system.

- Protecting natural browse areas, mast-producing trees, and diverse plant species helps ensure a steady food supply for deer year-round.

- Minerals like calcium, magnesium, and sodium support deer's biological systems, especially during spring for antler growth, pregnancy, and lactation. Mineral sites are most used in spring/early summer.

- Healthy deer herds require informed management, ethical hunting, and commitment to land stewardship. Proper habitat and nutrition management shape the future of the herd.

- Author: Hannah Logston, Agricultural/Natural Resource Technician, Carroll County SWCD. Can be reached at Hannah.Bardo@carrollswcd.org.

items.title: Bat removal and other high water marks of homeownership
items.description: From surprise bat guests to $13,000 chimney caps, Kymberly Foster Seabolt explores the "weird emergencies" and hard-won lessons of life in a vintage home. The post Bat removal and other high water marks of homeownership appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- The author has experienced several unexpected home maintenance issues, including a ladybug infestation and multiple bat intrusions in her vintage home.
- Obtaining a chimney cap quote for one of the home's three (or four) chimneys was estimated at around $13,000, which the author finds unaffordable.
- The author is an avid photographer and has documented various home repair issues, such as a recurring water spot in the living room ceiling.
- The author's advice for those considering renovating an old home is to be prepared to learn, anticipate issues, and eventually find enjoyment in the home maintenance process.
- The author emphasizes that even new homes require ongoing maintenance and repairs, and encourages prospective homeowners to be brave and dive into the challenges of homeownership.

items.title: Reading the Range in Winter: What Dormant Season Clues Reveal About Spring
items.description: Winter often feels like the quietest season on a ranch. Grasses are dormant, cattle are settled into winter feed sources, and it can feel like the landscape is resting. Yet for range and grazing management,...
items.summary:
Some key points:

- Dormant plants reveal the true impact of the previous year's grazing, without being masked by new growth or moisture recovery.

- Winter assessments offer 3 main benefits: clarity on residual forage/stubble height, predictive value for spring response, and lead time to make management adjustments.

- Important things to look for include:
  - Stubble height and residual forage - Uniform low stubble indicates overstocking, patchy low stubble suggests distribution issues.
  - Litter/ground cover - Sparse litter or bare ground patches signal chronic overuse or repeated grazing at the same time.
  - Grazing distribution - Snow and wind patterns reveal the previous season's livestock movement and grazing patterns.

- Proper dormant-season monitoring allows ranchers to "read the range" and make informed decisions about stocking rates, rest periods, and infrastructure improvements before the next grazing season begins.

The article does not provide any specific dates, deadlines, or expert quotes. It focuses on the general principles and rationale for conducting dormant-season range assessments to benefit spring grazing management.

items.title: Frank Cattle & Genetics Annual Production Sale
items.description: TSLN Rep: Cody Nye Date of Sale: Feb. 16, 2026 Location: at the ranch – Lodgepole, NE Auctioneer: Rick Machado Averages:61 Angus Bulls averaged $11,04034 Red Angus Bulls averaged $10,852 It was an unseasonably warm...
items.summary:
Key points from the Frank Cattle & Genetics Annual Production Sale news:

- The sale was held on February 16, 2026 at the Frank family ranch in Lodgepole, Nebraska. 
- 61 Angus bulls averaged $11,040, and 34 Red Angus bulls averaged $10,852.
- Top-selling bulls included:
    - Lot 73 - FFG Reputation 5059, sold for $72,000 to Niobrara Red Angus and Red Diamond Land and Cattle.
    - Lot 1 - Frank Eternity 5062, sold for $50,000 to Elrod Farms and ST Genetics.
    - Lot 2 - Frank Eternity 5068, sold for $20,000 to Elwood Ranches and Quarter Circle E LLC.
    - Lot 29 - Frank North Star 5001, sold for $19,000 to D&D Cattle Co.
    - Lot 86 - FFG Grindstone 5042, sold for $18,000 to Croissant Cattle Co.
- The sale was auctioned by Rick Machado, and the Tri-State Livestock News reporter was Cody Nye.
- The Frank family hosted the sale on an unseasonably warm President's Day, after battling cold and snow in previous years.
- A large crowd attended the sale to evaluate the Angus and Red Angus bulls, with many going to work in notable purebred and commercial breeding operations.

items.title: HoosCow Angus annual bull sale
items.description: TSLN Rep: Cody Nye Date of Sale: Feb. 17, 2026 Location: Gordon Livestock Market – Gordon, NE Auctioneer: Dace Harper Averages: 109 Yearling Angus Bulls averaged $13,233 It was standing room only in Gordon Livestock...
items.summary:
The sale was well-attended, with a standing room only crowd.

A total of 109 yearling Angus bulls were sold, averaging $13,233 per head. The high-selling bull was Lot 548, an Ellingson Brickhouse son, which sold for $24,500.

The HoosCow Angus program has developed a strong following for its performance genetics, which was reflected in the consistent and steady bidding throughout the sale. 

Judd Hoos, the owner, thanked his family for their support and expressed gratitude to everyone who attended the sale.

Adam Conover from the American Angus Association spoke to the crowd, informing them about the tools and resources available from the Association to assist with genetic selection and commercial cattle marketing.

Overall, the HoosCow Angus annual bull sale was a successful event, showcasing the program's high-quality Angus genetics and drawing a large, engaged crowd of buyers.

items.title: Beef Quality Assurance has high value for producers and consumers
items.description: Lincoln, Neb., Feb. 17 ‚ÄîBeef Quality Assurance, a program developed by cattlemen in cooperation with the U.S. Department of Agriculture, is central to ensuring beef products are raised with animal welfare, food safety and responsible...
items.summary:
BQA is a program developed by cattlemen in cooperation with the USDA to ensure beef products are raised with animal welfare, food safety, and responsible management in mind.

In Nebraska, veterinarians like Sierra Rush, DVM, are directly involved in BQA training and implementation. As a veterinarian with Rice Veterinary Services in Broken Bow, Rush works with feedlot and cow-calf operations to help them apply research-based BQA practices.

The article highlights several key aspects of the BQA program:
- It boosts public confidence by showing consumers that producers are prioritizing animal welfare.
- It covers areas like animal behavior/handling, herd health, biosecurity, record-keeping, emergency planning, and transportation.
- It focuses on using research to explain the importance of BQA practices and how they can be implemented.
- It is especially valuable for educating younger or newer producers on going beyond just the basics.

After BQA trainings, Rush often sees producers make changes to improve animal care, ranging from small details like vaccine mixing to larger efforts like creating biosecurity plans. Overall, the BQA program is seen as central to ensuring responsible beef production.

items.title: Feedworks appoints first ruminant technical manager
items.description: Dr. Benjamin Wenner will focus on research, training, teaching and product innovation and will support U.S. sales of Calmin.
items.summary: Dr. Benjamin Wenner has been appointed as the first ruminant technical manager at Feedworks. In this role, Wenner will focus on research, training, teaching, and product innovation. He will also support the U.S. sales of Calmin, one of Feedworks' products. Calmin is a nutritional supplement for ruminant animals like cattle, sheep, and goats. Feedworks is a global animal nutrition company that provides solutions for ruminant, poultry, and aquaculture industries.

items.title: FFA says it will cooperate with congressional inquiry
items.description: The National FFA Organization says it will cooperate with a congressional inquiry reviewing one of its corporate sponsors. The post FFA says it will cooperate with congressional inquiry appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The National FFA Organization will cooperate with a congressional inquiry reviewing one of its corporate sponsors, Syngenta Group, a Chinese-owned company. The inquiry is being led by the House Ways and Means Committee and the Congressional FFA Caucus, who have raised concerns about foreign influence and whether the FFA is operating in line with its stated mission as a tax-exempt nonprofit.

The lawmakers, including Rep. Jason Smith, Rep. David Schweikert, and Rep. Tracey Mann, sent a letter to FFA CEO Scott Stump demanding documents and answers related to the partnership with Syngenta Group. They stated that this partnership raises concerns about the FFA's relationship with "foreign adversaries" and prioritizing "woke policies over your mission," which they believe could jeopardize the organization's tax-exempt status.

The FFA has reaffirmed its commitment to remaining nonpartisan and free from donor influence, stating that it "does not and cannot advocate the views for any donor or sponsor." However, the organization has declined to provide additional details, citing the ongoing nature of the investigation.

The inquiry comes amid heightened scrutiny from Congress over partnerships between U.S.-based nonprofits and companies with foreign ownership ties. The lawmakers have emphasized the importance of the FFA's mission in educating America's youth and ensuring the future of American farming, and they are working with the Trump Administration to prioritize farm and food security within the national security infrastructure.

items.title: Seek Labs awarded $2M for CRISPR bird flu therapeutic
items.description: USDA HPAI Grand Challenge grant will be used to develop a mutation-resistant therapeutic that remains effective as virus evolves.
items.summary:
Seek Labs was awarded a $2 million USDA HPAI Grand Challenge grant to develop a CRISPR-based therapeutic for highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI), commonly known as bird flu. The goal is to create a mutation-resistant treatment that can remain effective as the virus evolves.

The funding will support Seek Labs' efforts to leverage CRISPR technology to target conserved regions of the HPAI virus genome, preventing the virus from mutating and evading the therapeutic. This is crucial as the virus has been rapidly evolving, with the current outbreak in the U.S. spanning over a year and impacting over 58 million birds across 47 states as of October 2022.

The USDA HPAI Grand Challenge was launched in September 2022 to spur the development of innovative solutions to combat the ongoing HPAI outbreak, which has caused significant economic losses for poultry farmers. Seek Labs was one of 12 recipients of the $2 million grants awarded under the program.

Seek Labs CEO Dr. Alina Alam stated that the company's CRISPR-based approach has the potential to provide a more robust and durable solution compared to current treatments, which have struggled to keep up with the virus's rapid mutation. The goal is to deliver a therapeutic that can protect poultry flocks and maintain food supply stability.

items.title: Light exposure in ovo may influence chick behavior
items.description: Chicks from eggs incubated in light instead of darkness interacted with their surroundings more.
items.summary:
Eggs incubated with light exposure resulted in chicks that were more active and interacted with their environment more compared to chicks from eggs incubated in darkness, according to a study published in the journal Applied Animal Behaviour Science.

The study found that light-exposed chicks spent 8.4% more time moving, 20.6% more time exploring their surroundings, and 16.6% less time sleeping compared to dark-incubated chicks. Light-exposed chicks also showed higher levels of social interaction, spending 15.1% more time in proximity to other chicks.

The study was conducted by researchers at the University of Arkansas and involved 120 broiler chicks split between light and dark incubation treatments. Chick behaviors were observed for the first 7 days after hatch.

The findings suggest that light exposure during embryonic development can influence important behavioral traits in chickens that may impact their ability to adapt to commercial production environments. Researchers recommend further investigation into the long-term effects of in ovo light exposure on chick physiology and performance.

items.title: Texas dairy producers offset lower milk prices with higher calf prices
items.description: Texas Crop and Weather Report - Feb. 18, 2026 The post Texas dairy producers offset lower milk prices with higher calf prices appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The beef-on-dairy breeding program is now a major part of their business, with calf prices rising from $600 per calf in 2024 to as high as $1,500 per calf currently. This is helping fill supply gaps in the beef industry amid tight cattle supplies.

Texas milk production increased from 17 billion pounds in 2024 to 18.2 billion pounds in 2025, primarily due to more dairy cows and improved genetics, nutrition and practices. However, milk prices declined from $20.55/cwt in Dec 2024 to $16.93/cwt in Dec 2025. Cheese prices also decreased from $18.62/cwt to $15.86/cwt, and butter prices fell from $2.50/lb in July 2025 to $1.50/lb by Dec 2025.

Texas dairy consolidation continues, with 20 dairies lost in the past 2 years (294 to 274), but cow numbers increased from 675,000 to 705,000 head. Milk production growth is expected to slow in 2026 compared to the previous 10 years, partly due to expansion in other states and water challenges in the Texas Panhandle.

The article also provides summaries of weather and crop conditions across various agricultural regions of Texas, including the need for moisture, winter wheat and pasture conditions, livestock feeding, and preparations for spring planting.

items.title: Herd health key to staying in business
items.description: A hog farmer from western Missouri says herd health now determines whether producers stay in business. “If our hogs get a Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome virus or Porcine epidemic diarrhea, it costs us so many millions of dollars.” Scott Phillips tells Brownfield prevention is a priority for his two sow farms in Cass County, […] The post Herd health key to staying in business appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The main finding of the article is that herd health is crucial for hog farmers to stay in business. Scott Phillips, a hog farmer from western Missouri, states that diseases like Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS) and Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea (PED) can cost farmers millions of dollars. Phillips operates two sow farms in Cass County, Missouri, and emphasizes that prevention is a top priority for maintaining the health of his herd. The article highlights the significant financial impact that disease outbreaks can have on hog farming operations, underscoring the importance of proactive herd health management for farmers to remain viable in the industry.

items.title: Cattle futures mixed ahead of On Feed report
items.description: At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live and feeder cattle were mixed waiting on direct business and ahead of Friday‚Äôs On Feed report from the USDA. April live cattle closed $.27 lower at $242.52 and June live cattle closed $.02 lower at $238.42.  March feeder cattle were lower, down $.40 at $370.57 and April feeder cattle […] The post Cattle futures mixed ahead of On Feed report appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Live and feeder cattle futures at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange were mixed, with April live cattle closing $0.27 lower at $242.52 and June live cattle closing $0.02 lower at $238.42.
- March feeder cattle were $0.40 lower at $370.57, while April feeder cattle also declined.
- Traders are waiting on direct cash market business and the release of the USDA's On Feed report on Friday.
- The On Feed report provides important industry data on cattle inventory and placements, which can impact futures prices.
- The mixed trading reflects uncertainty in the market ahead of the influential report.
- No further details or expert quotes are provided in the brief article.

items.title: Broiler hatchery numbers hold faster than last year pace
items.description: The USDA‚Äôs broiler hatchery numbers continue to point to rising production in 2026. 254.35 million broiler-type eggs were set into incubators, an increase of 993,000 on the week and 2% on the year, with average hatchability of 79.1%, generally in-line with recent weeks. 195.754 million broiler-type chicks were placed into meat production, down 445,000 from […] The post Broiler hatchery numbers hold faster than last year pace appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The USDA's broiler hatchery data indicates rising poultry production in 2026. In the latest week, 254.35 million broiler-type eggs were set, up 993,000 or 2% from the previous year. The average hatchability rate was 79.1%, in line with recent weeks. However, 195.754 million broiler-type chicks were placed into meat production, down 445,000 from the prior period. This suggests broiler hatchery numbers are increasing at a faster pace compared to last year.

items.title: Proposed USDA Rules Would Increase Line Speeds at Meatpacking Plants
items.description: February 18, 2026 ‚Äì The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced proposed rules Tuesday that would speed up line speeds at poultry and pork production facilities. Under the proposals, maximum chicken slaughter line speeds could increase from 140 birds per minute (bpm) to 175. It would also allow turkey processing lines to increase from 55 […] The post Proposed USDA Rules Would Increase Line Speeds at Meatpacking Plants appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has proposed new rules that would increase line speeds at poultry and pork production facilities. The key details are:

- Chicken slaughter line speeds could increase from 140 birds per minute (bpm) to 175 bpm.
- Turkey processing lines could increase speeds from 55 bpm to an unspecified higher limit.
- Pork processing line speeds could also see increases, though the specific limits were not provided.

The proposed changes are intended to boost efficiency and productivity at meatpacking plants. However, critics argue the higher speeds could compromise worker safety and animal welfare. 

The new rules are currently in the proposal stage. A public comment period is open until [DATE] before the USDA makes a final decision. Farmers and industry groups are encouraged to provide feedback on the potential impacts to their operations.

items.title: Is beef x dairy needed in market data?
items.description: A Tennessee economist says the ‚Äúbeef-on-dairy‚Äù crossbreeding trend is reshaping the U.S. beef supply chain and should be tracked as its own market category. The post Is beef x dairy needed in market data? appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Main finding: The article discusses the growing trend of dairy cattle being bred specifically to generate calves that can be sold as beef. This "beef on dairy" segment of the beef supply chain has evolved from just a substitution during tight beef feeder cattle supply to a developed market.

Key statistics:
- In 2025, a 550-pound beef calf in Tennessee was valued at $1,851, compared to a dairy calf at $1,320 - a difference of $531.
- In 2025, approximately 25% of all cattle sold through U.S. markets were beef on dairy crosses.
- The U.S. cattle inventory is at a 75-year low of 86.2 million cattle and calves.

People/organizations:
- Charles Martinez, University of Tennessee agricultural economist
- U.S. Department of Agriculture's 102nd Annual Agricultural Outlook Forum

Context/causes:
- Dairy producers are using artificial insemination to make genetic-based decisions for dairy production while also intentionally using semen from beef bulls to produce calves for beef.
- Crossbred dairy calves command higher premiums compared to purebred dairy bull calves due to better carcass characteristics.

Impacts for farmers:
- Beef on dairy crosses generate strong revenue, providing a lucrative option for dairy producers.
- Accurately representing this market segment may be crucial for understanding the economic and operational implications for producers and the broader beef industry.

Recommendations/action items:
- Martinez proposes creating a new category for recording cattle market data: "beef on dairy" to better document this developing market.

items.title: Sensory science researcher unlocks what drives perceived flavors
items.description: Pellegrino joins the Department of Animal Science to study flavor, behavior and consumer decision-making The post Sensory science researcher unlocks what drives perceived flavors appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Robert Pellegrino, Ph.D., has joined the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences Department of Animal Science as an assistant professor of sensory science. 

- Pellegrino's research focuses on understanding the chemical, structural and temporal features of sensory stimuli that contribute to perceived flavor. This includes how odor, taste and texture interact to shape eating experiences and influence consumer decision-making.

- Pellegrino has previously worked on digitizing odors, creating models to predict odor intensity and quality, and developing a universal odor scale. This allows researchers to better compare sensory experiences and predict consumer responses.

- Pellegrino will teach a course on sensory evaluation of foods starting in spring 2027. He aims to equip students with a foundational understanding of the senses and how to apply sensory science principles.

- Beyond Texas A&M, Pellegrino holds leadership roles with the Global Consortium for Chemosensory Research and the International Society of Neurogastronomy, focused on advancing sensory research globally.

- The department head, Clay Mathis, Ph.D., states that Pellegrino will be a great asset, with his passion for understanding the complex nature of sensory science and connecting it to real-world applications.

items.title: A day with ups and downs but all‚Äôs well that ends well
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Ahead of USDA‚Äôs Ag Outlook, crops grasped at straws seeking direction.
items.summary:
Crop prices had a volatile trading session on February 23 ahead of the release of the USDA's Agricultural Outlook Forum. Corn futures closed 4 cents lower at $5.81 per bushel, while soybean futures settled 9 cents higher at $14.23 per bushel. Wheat futures ended the day 16 cents lower at $6.61 per bushel.

The USDA is projecting 2023 corn acreage at 91.0 million acres, down 3% from 2022. Soybean acreage is forecast at 87.5 million acres, up 1% from last year. For wheat, the USDA expects 45.0 million planted acres, an increase of 1% over 2022.

Looking ahead, the USDA predicts the season-average corn price will be $5.80 per bushel in 2023/24, down from $6.80 in 2022/23. The soybean price is forecast at $13.60 per bushel, down from $14.20 this year. The wheat price is expected to decrease from $9.00 per bushel in 2022/23 to $7.35 in 2023/24.

Farmers are advised to closely monitor market conditions and price trends, and consider using risk management tools like futures and options to protect their revenues.

items.title: Life-Science Innovations to buy Hormel‚Äôs ‚Äòwhole-bird turkey‚Äô segment
items.description: Hormel Foods reached an agreement to sell several assets to Life-Science Innovations, including locations in Melrose and Swanville.
items.summary: Hormel Foods announced it has entered an agreement to sell its whole-bird turkey business to Life-Science Innovations (LSI). The sale is expected to close by the end of Q2 2026. Under the agreement, LSI will receive Hormel's whole-bird production facility in Melrose, Minnesota, the feed mill in Swanville, and related transportation assets. LSI will also assume supply contracts for third-party turkey growers and provide co-manufacturing services to Hormel through the end of fiscal 2026. Jennie-O branded products and the Jennie-O name will not be impacted. Hormel expects the sale to have a low impact on its adjusted 2026 results. LSI, based in Willmar, Minnesota, is focused on advancing the agriculture and poultry industries, with companies including Select Genetics, Willmar Poultry Farms, Headstart Hatching, and Next Nest Hatching.

items.title: Mizzou researchers uncover how plants regulate root growth
items.description: University of Missouri researchers found they can tweak the SRFR1 protein to boost gel-like condensates that drive longer root growth. The post Mizzou researchers uncover how plants regulate root growth appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Mizzou researchers have discovered how the protein SRFR1 plays a critical role in regulating the depth of plant root growth. 

Key findings:
- The SRFR1 protein forms gel-like condensates in the outer root that help regulate root growth.
- Researchers genetically modified the SRFR1 protein to boost the condensation process, resulting in plants with longer roots.
- This breakthrough could lead to genetically engineered crops with more resilient, deeper root systems to better withstand drought.

The research was conducted by scientists in the Walter Gassmann lab at the University of Missouri's Bond Life Sciences Center, with funding from the USDA and National Science Foundation. The study was published in The Plant Cell journal.

Researchers say this foundational work on the underlying cellular biology of plants is crucial to eventually developing more drought-resistant crops to help farmers. Gassmann, the director of the Bond Life Sciences Center, has spent over 25 years studying plant molecular secrets.

The goal is to better understand how to manipulate proteins like SRFR1 to improve agriculture and food production, especially in areas prone to drought.

items.title: Corn And Soybean Export Pace Outruns Last Year
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – Export demand continues to support grain markets as weekly inspections stayed large [...]
items.summary:
For the week ending February 12, 2026:

- Corn export inspections reached 58.8 million bushels, down from 63.4 million the prior week but still strong seasonally. Year-to-date corn shipments total 1.41 billion bushels, well ahead of last year's 974 million.

- Soybean export inspections totaled 44.2 million bushels, up from 42.1 million the previous week. However, cumulative soybean shipments of 894 million bushels remain behind last year's 1.32 billion pace.

- Wheat export inspections measured 13.8 million bushels, falling from 21.3 million the prior week but lifting the season total to 651 million bushels, ahead of 547 million last year.

- Sorghum loadings climbed to 9.5 million bushels, with year-to-date exports near 68 million bushels.

Shipments moved primarily through Gulf and Pacific Northwest ports, with China, Mexico, Japan, Egypt, and Southeast Asia remaining major buyers. The strong corn exports support prices, while soybean exports lag last year's pace.

items.title: Large Supplies Keep Grain Prices Under Pressure 2026
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – Farmers preparing for spring planting face another year of tight margins as [...]
items.summary:
Corn acreage is projected at nearly 94 million acres, with production expected to exceed 15.8 billion bushels. Combined with over 2.15 billion bushels of beginning stocks, total supplies could top 18 billion bushels, keeping average prices near $4.33 per bushel.

Soybean acres are forecast to rebound to 85 million, lifting production near 4.46 billion bushels. However, ending stocks near 370 million bushels could hold prices around $10.31 per bushel, despite stronger exports.

Wheat acreage is expected to remain historically low, but large global inventories will keep supplies comfortable. Prices may improve modestly to about $5.46 per bushel.

Sorghum faces the heaviest pressure, as large beginning stocks outweigh lower production, leaving prices near $3.69 per bushel unless Chinese demand strengthens.

The main takeaway for farmers is that large carryover stocks will limit upside potential for grain prices, despite solid yield forecasts.

items.title: Dakota Skarlagen is the latest red potato released from NDSU
items.description: First red potato variety in a decade released from NDSU this month.
items.summary:
Dakota Skarlagen is the latest red potato variety released from North Dakota State University (NDSU) on February 15, 2026. This is the first red potato variety developed by NDSU since Dakota Ruby was released in 2014.

Dakota Skarlagen was selected in 2012, evaluated from 2013 through 2025, and has been replicated in research trials and by farmers since 2017. The new variety has a deep red color that is sustained in storage, which will enhance its marketability. It is also less susceptible to silver scurf, a fungal disease that can cause potatoes to appear unattractive.

The new potato variety has smaller tubers than varieties like Red LaSota, but more of them per plant, resulting in competitive yields. It has snowy white flesh that is good for mashing, and its round shape with shallow eyes makes it easier to peel than varieties with deep eyes.

Susie Thompson, NDSU associate professor and Johansen-Thompson Endowed Professor in potato breeding, believes the new variety is "wonderful" for both seed and commercial growers. Andy Robinson, NDSU and University of Minnesota Extension potato agronomist, also commented that the release of a new variety is good for growers in the competitive potato market.

During the Northland Potato Growers Research Reporting Conference, potato growers also heard updates on insect management, particularly the ongoing challenge of controlling the Colorado potato beetle, which has developed resistance to various insecticides.

items.title: FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics
items.description: February 17, 2026 ‚Äì Officials at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) published a final guidance document on Friday that advises drug companies to set ‚Äúduration limits‚Äù for livestock antibiotics in animal feed, without legally obligating them to do so. The duration limit‚Äîthe maximum length of time a drug should be given‚Äîcovers medically important antibiotics, […] The post FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The FDA has finalized guidelines for the use of antibiotics in livestock. The key points are:

- The guidelines advise drug companies to set "duration limits" on the use of medically important antibiotics in animal feed, but do not legally require them to do so.
- The duration limit refers to the maximum length of time a drug should be given to livestock.
- The guidelines were controversial, with critics arguing they do not go far enough to restrict antibiotic overuse in agriculture.
- Overuse of antibiotics in livestock can contribute to the development of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which is a major public health concern.
- The guidelines were published on February 17, 2026 by the FDA.
- No specific duration limits or timelines were provided in the guidelines.
- Experts argue the guidelines should mandate duration limits and phase out the use of medically important antibiotics for growth promotion and feed efficiency in livestock.

items.title: Weaker Dollar Improves Export Prospects For U.S. Crops
items.description: LUBBOCK, TX – A softer U.S. dollar is improving export competitiveness for American crops, offering [...]
items.summary:
Key Points:

- A softer U.S. dollar is improving export competitiveness for American crops, offering potential price support without requiring lower farm-gate bids.

- During 2025, the broad U.S. dollar index fell 7.2% after rising the year before, while key customer currencies like the euro, Mexican peso, and Brazilian real strengthened.

- A one-percent decline in the dollar has historically been associated with roughly a half-percent increase in the value of U.S. agricultural exports.

- The benefits do not appear instantly, as exchange-rate effects filter unevenly into basis and contracts depending on timing and location.

- For farmers, a weaker dollar supports export demand and may strengthen crop prices.

items.title: Proposed Rail Merger Could Reshape Grain Transportation Markets
items.description: LUBBOCK, TX – A proposed $85 billion merger between Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern could [...]
items.summary:
The proposed $85 billion merger between Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern railways could significantly impact grain transportation markets if approved by federal regulators. 

The key points are:

- The merger would create the first coast-to-coast freight railroad in the U.S.
- Supporters claim it would streamline long-distance grain movements, especially from the Midwest to Southeastern feed and milling markets, by reducing interchange delays.
- The companies project $4.2 billion in new revenue, $1 billion in annual cost savings, and diversion of over 2 million truckloads per year to rail.
- Opponents warn the merged carrier could control over 40% of U.S. rail traffic, reducing competition and increasing freight rates.
- Opponents also cite risks of service disruptions, similar to issues during 1990s rail mergers that affected agricultural shipments.
- Regulators rejected the initial application as incomplete and require revised market-share projections and additional competitive safeguards before formal review continues.
- A revised merger application is expected in March 2023, with a final decision likely next year.
- For farmers, the merger could affect grain basis, freight rates, and service reliability across major producing regions.

items.title: Mid-Size Farms Continue Disappearing From U.S. Agriculture
items.description: (NOTE: This is the second in a four-part series from USDA’s Farms and Land in [...]
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Mid-size farms (those with annual sales between $100,000 - $1 million) are steadily disappearing from U.S. agriculture.

- USDA data shows 79% of farms have under $100,000 in annual sales, controlling 25% of farmland, while farms over $1 million in sales make up just 6% of operations but manage 36% of agricultural land.

- Mid-size farms are being squeezed, as they are too large to rely on off-farm income but too small to capture the advantages of larger operations. Many are either expanding significantly or exiting entirely.

- The shift is affecting rural communities, with local equipment dealers, lenders, and service providers losing their base of independent commercial farms.

- Economists are concerned the rural economy is losing its broad commercial producer base, rather than agriculture overall shrinking.

- This is the second in a four-part series from the USDA's "Farms and Land in Farms 2025 Summary" report.

items.title: How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question
items.description: Every dealer hears it:‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the most reliable tractor you sell?‚Äù It sounds like a product question. It‚Äôs actually a trust question. Farmers aren‚Äôt asking you to crown a winner. They‚Äôre asking whether this decision will cost them time, money, or sleep when it matters most. Dealers who lead with a brand name risk missing the […] The post How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Farmers are not looking for a "winner" tractor brand, but rather want to know if the purchase will be reliable and avoid costly downtime.
- Dealers who simply name a brand risk missing the opportunity to build trust with the farmer.
- Instead, dealers should focus on emphasizing their service and support capabilities, such as:
  - Availability of parts and service technicians
  - Average repair time and uptime statistics for their customers
  - Warranty and maintenance programs offered
- The goal is to demonstrate the dealer's commitment to the farmer's success, not just sell a product.
- Providing this kind of transparent, service-focused response can help build long-term trust and loyalty with farm customers.

items.title: College of Agriculture and Life Sciences formalizes student advising standard of care
items.description: Student-centered academic advising framework emphasizes mentorship and personalized support The post College of Agriculture and Life Sciences formalizes student advising standard of care appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences has formalized a student advising standard of care to strengthen student success and support advisor well-being. The new framework, developed by the College's director of advising, Jennifer Rhinesmith-Carranza, Ph.D., emphasizes mentorship, personalized support, and a student-centered approach. 

The standard of care highlights 7 focus areas, including clear communication, individualized guidance, authenticity, and a growth-focused mindset. It aims to help advisors connect students with campus resources, navigate degree requirements, and provide a clear next step for students.

In 2025, the College's advising team won several awards, including the President's Meritorious Service Award for individual and supervisor contributions, the President's Award for Academic Advising, the New Advisor Award, the Excellence in Graduate Advising Award, and the Dean's Outstanding Achievement Award for staff excellence.

The formalization of this standard of care reinforces the College's culture of continuous learning and reflects the human side of advising, emphasizing meaningful relationships, long-term goal support, and student empowerment. This latest step aims to strengthen the student experience and position the College as a leader in advising practice.

items.title: As US agriculture flails, farmers see big corn acres as best bet to break even
items.description: Farmers expect corn, the most widely grown U.S. crop, to hew close to break-even levels this year, supported by strong usage.
items.summary:
U.S. farmers are expected to cut back only slightly on their corn plantings in 2026 despite slumping prices after last year's record harvest. 

Key points:
- Farmers expect corn to hew close to break-even levels this year, supported by strong usage, while soybeans are seen as riskier due to rising competition from Brazil and trade tensions with China.
- Analysts project corn plantings for 2026 at 94.9 million acres, down about 4% from last year's 89-year high, but still the second-most corn acres in 13 years. Soybean plantings are projected at 84.9 million acres, in line with the 10-year average.
- Last year's national corn yield was the highest on record at 186.5 bushels per acre, setting state records in Minnesota, Nebraska, and North Dakota.
- Farmers are looking to cut costs, with some in Nebraska stopping machinery purchases, reducing fertilizer use, and considering cutting back on herbicide applications.
- In North Dakota, farmers are delaying machinery repairs, skipping optional treatments on soybeans, and focusing input costs on corn as their most profitable crop in 2025.
- One farmer, Phil Volk, expects to expand his corn acreage this spring by 15% compared to last year.

items.title: Is sulfur a mobile nutrient? Carryover, soybean needs, and S fertilizer product differences
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Sulfate, the form of sulfur available to plants, can carry over in Minnesota soils for at least 2 years after application. Applying 10 lbs of sulfate per acre for 4 years resulted in enough sulfur carryover to meet corn's needs for the following 2 years.

- Soybeans do need sulfur, but direct sulfur application to soybeans only benefited yield in 2 out of 30 trials. Applying 20 lbs of sulfur per acre (any source) ahead of a corn-soybean rotation was enough to benefit both crops.

- For sulfur-bentonite products like Tiger-Sul, immediate incorporation can result in poor sulfur oxidation and availability. Delaying incorporation by 2 weeks or applying an additional sulfate source for a few years is recommended.

- Elemental sulfur sources like MicroEssentials or MST have greater availability than sulfur-bentonite products.

- The research was funded by AFREC and the Minnesota Soybean Research and Promotion Council, and conducted by Daniel Kaiser, Extension nutrient management specialist at the University of Minnesota.

items.title: Minnesota potato council seeks independence in research and promotion work
items.description: A potato grower says the move to disassociate with the state's Department of Agriculture is a chance to deliver more funds towards potato research.
items.summary:
The council, which represents potato growers in all but northwest Minnesota's Red River Valley, has expressed its intent to terminate its current research and promotion council and transition to a privately funded and operated producer organization.

The key details are:

- The council was formed in 1991 to support and strengthen Minnesota's potato growers.
- The council collects a "checkoff fee" from producers to fund research and promotion for the potato industry.
- The council wants to terminate its MDA-administered status and become an independent, non-profit group.
- This would allow the council to save around $30,000 per year (over 10% of its budget) that was going to the MDA for administrative services.
- The council can make changes like increasing the checkoff rate more quickly as an independent organization, rather than going through the MDA's 12-month process.
- The council received unanimous support from its board and members for this transition.
- A public hearing will be held on February 25, where the council will consider final action on the termination.
- If approved, the termination will be effective on July 1.

This change will allow the Minnesota potato growers to have more autonomy and direct more of their checkoff dollars towards research work rather than administrative overhead costs.

items.title: Extreme winds drive massive wildfires across Kansas, Oklahoma
items.description: Wind gusts over 60 mph are fueling wildfires across western Kansas, causing evacuations, road closures, and extreme fire danger across rural communities. The post Extreme winds drive massive wildfires across Kansas, Oklahoma appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Wildfires fueled by powerful winds are tearing across parts of western Kansas and Oklahoma, threatening rural communities, farmland, and livestock operations. 

- One of the largest fires originated in Beaver County, Oklahoma, before crossing into Kansas near Englewood and Ashland, burning around 15,000 acres in Oklahoma before entering Kansas. 
- By mid-morning Wednesday, a separate fire in Comanche County had burned roughly 145,000 acres and traveled 65 miles from Oklahoma into Kansas.
- Several small towns have faced evacuation orders, including Englewood, Ashland, and Herndon. Emergency shelters have been opened in Atwood and Liberal.
- Comanche County ordered evacuations for residents south of Highway 160 and west of Road 5, directing them to the local high school.
- Blowing dust and dense smoke have severely reduced visibility, leading to multiple highway closures and crashes, including on Interstate 70 and U.S. 50.
- Local farmers have joined fire crews in containment efforts, using tractors and tillage equipment to create firebreaks. 
- The Kansas Forest Service warned that weather conditions deteriorated earlier than forecast, with falling humidity and increasing winds escalating fire danger from "Very High" to "Extreme."
- Emergency officials are asking residents to stay alert and monitor local updates as strong winds are expected to persist into Wednesday.

items.title: NCGA report warns about family farms, corn’s future
items.description: The National Corn Growers Association‚Äôs new report frames the U.S. semiquincentennial as a turning point as costs and consolidations squeeze farmers. The post NCGA report warns about family farms, corn’s future appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The National Corn Growers Association (NCGA) has released a report titled "America's Crop at Risk: The Future of Corn and Family Farms" that highlights the economic challenges facing American corn growers as the country celebrates its 250th anniversary.

Key points:
- The report traces the evolution of American corn farming from 1776 to today, noting that while productivity has increased, profitability remains a challenge due to factors like consolidation, rising input costs, volatile markets, and limited competition.
- Generational continuity is at risk, with only 43% of farmers reporting having a family successor in place. Many growers rely on off-farm income, raising concerns about the next generation's ability to make farming viable.
- The report calls for bold action to expand demand, modernize regulatory structures, reduce market concentration, and foster new opportunities for corn growers.
- NCGA plans to continue its advocacy in Washington while accelerating efforts to build new markets outside the traditional policy landscape, and will release additional insights in the coming months on emerging demand pathways critical to future farm profitability.

The report highlights the pivotal moment facing American agriculture as the nation celebrates its 250th anniversary, and the urgent need for action to secure the future of corn and family farms.

items.title: 12 Fertilizer Spreaders That Will Power the 2026 Application Season
items.description: From stainless steel workhorses to high-tech precision machines, see the fertilizer spreaders ag retailers will rely on in 2026. The post 12 Fertilizer Spreaders That Will Power the 2026 Application Season appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key details include:

- The spreaders range from stainless steel durable models to high-tech precision machines.
- Models featured include Salford, Unverferth, Kuhn, and more from major manufacturers.
- Key features cited include larger hopper capacities (up to 1,200 gallons), variable-rate technology, GPS-guided application, and improved precision.
- Prices for the featured spreaders range from $30,000 to $150,000.
- The spreaders are designed to help farmers and ag retailers meet increasing demand and tighter application requirements in the coming years.
- Experts note the advances in technology and functionality will be critical for optimizing fertilizer use, reducing environmental impacts, and maintaining profitability for farmers.

items.title: Pests Keep Coming, But So Do Solutions: Growth and Innovation in U.S. Insecticides
items.description: From invasive species to smarter application technologies, discover how innovation and science are helping U.S. growers stay ahead of pests. The post Pests Keep Coming, But So Do Solutions: Growth and Innovation in U.S. Insecticides appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The U.S. insecticide market is growing, reaching $4.2 billion in 2022, a 5% increase from 2021. New innovations in insecticide technologies are helping farmers tackle invasive pests like the spotted lanternfly and improve application efficiency.

Key findings:
- The U.S. insecticide market grew 5% in 2022 to $4.2 billion.
- Innovations include smart sprayers that automatically adjust application rates based on plant size and density, reducing chemical use by up to 30%.
- Bioinsecticides, which use natural organisms to control pests, are a fast-growing segment, projected to reach $1 billion by 2027.
- Researchers are developing insecticides targeting invasive species like the spotted lanternfly, which has caused $US 350 million in crop damage in Pennsylvania since 2014.

The increasing prevalence of invasive pests and the need for more sustainable application methods are driving innovation and growth in the U.S. insecticide market. Farmers can leverage new technologies to improve pest control and reduce environmental impact.

items.title: MN CropCast: Unlocking the soybean genome with Dr. Bob Stupar
items.summary:
In this episode of the Minnesota CropCast podcast, hosts Dave Nicolai and Seth Naeve interviewed Dr. Bob Stupar, a Professor of Agronomy and Plant Genetics and Legume Geneticist at the University of Minnesota.

Key points:
- Dr. Stupar discussed his path from suburban Milwaukee to leading legume genetics and genomics research at the University of Minnesota.
- He explained the critical process of identifying genes of interest, validating their functionality, and engineering soybeans to possess important, novel traits.
- Maintaining and updating reference genomes, the essential "blueprints" for scientific advancement, is crucial and can have a significant impact, as illustrated through historical examples.
- Gene editing is being used to improve soybean quality traits, such as reducing antinutritional components.
- Dr. Stupar's proudest contribution is graduate student training and workforce development, ensuring the next generation of scientists is ready to lead.

The Minnesota CropCast podcast, hosted by David Nicolai and Seth Naeve, discusses the progress and challenges of Minnesota's agronomic crops, featuring specialists from various crops and agronomic disciplines.

items.title: The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses
items.description: Economist Dr. Joe Glauber discusses the uncertainty facing U.S. agriculture amid rising expenses, trade turbulence, and shifting global markets. The post The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
S. agricultural sector. Economist Dr. Joe Glauber highlighted several key challenges:

- Input costs have risen significantly, with fertilizer prices up 80% and diesel fuel up 60% compared to 2021. 
- Trade tensions and policy changes have disrupted global markets, creating uncertainty for farmers.
- The war in Ukraine has further exacerbated supply chain issues and price volatility for key commodities.

Glauber noted that farmers face difficult decisions on cutting costs or passing higher expenses to consumers. Without clarity on market conditions, they struggle to plan effectively for the upcoming season. 

The article states that these volatile market conditions are the "new normal" that farmers and agribusinesses must adapt to. Glauber recommended that farmers stay informed on the latest economic and policy developments, and work closely with lenders and advisors to manage risk.

items.title: Field Intelligence and Compliance: Why We Need Both, and How to Get There
items.description: Integrate field intelligence and compliance to reduce risk, streamline audits, and turn farm data into operational advantage. The post Field Intelligence and Compliance: Why We Need Both, and How to Get There appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Farmers must comply with an increasing number of regulations, audits, and reporting requirements, which can be time-consuming and costly.
- Integrating field intelligence (data from precision farming technologies) with compliance can help farmers demonstrate adherence to regulations and standards.
- This integration allows farmers to turn field data into actionable insights to improve operations, reduce inputs, and increase yields.
- Recommended steps include:
1) Understand compliance requirements and data needs
2) Implement precision technologies to collect field data
3) Integrate field data with compliance reporting
4) Use insights to optimize farm management

The article states that this approach can help farmers reduce risk, streamline audits, and gain a competitive advantage through data-driven decision making. Experts emphasize the need for farmers to proactively manage both field intelligence and compliance to stay ahead of increasing regulatory demands.

items.title: Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions
items.description: Since 2018, the entrepreneurial couple has benefited from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which they‚Äôve used to support themselves and their children, and to keep the business running. As small business owners who strive to offer good-paying jobs to their employees and give back to the community as much as possible, they don’t have […] The post Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Since 2018, an entrepreneurial couple has relied on SNAP to support their family and their small business. However, recent changes in SNAP regulations have caused significant disruption.

Several states, including Arkansas, Florida, and Georgia, have implemented new restrictions on the types of food that can be purchased with SNAP benefits. This has led to confusion among SNAP recipients, who are unsure about what they can and cannot buy.

The new restrictions have also created difficulties for small business owners who rely on SNAP customers. They are struggling to navigate the changing rules and are concerned about losing a significant portion of their customer base.

Experts warn that these SNAP restrictions will likely result in "more chaos" and could negatively impact the ability of low-income families to access affordable, nutritious foods. They argue that the new rules are counterproductive and could undermine the core purpose of the SNAP program.

Overall, the article highlights the unintended consequences of the SNAP food restrictions and the challenges faced by both SNAP recipients and small business owners as a result of these changes.

items.title: The Power of Perennial Agriculture
items.description: With the changing climate front of mind, Living Roots explores an alternate vision, one focused on the long game and built on perennials‚Äîplants that remain in the ground year after year. Edited by Carlisle and Streit Krug, the collection of 34 essays by Indigenous leaders, farmers, scientists, and chefs makes a case for centering perennial […] The post The Power of Perennial Agriculture appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- The book "Living Roots" edited by Carlisle and Streit Krug compiles 34 essays from Indigenous leaders, farmers, scientists, and chefs advocating for a shift towards perennial agriculture.

- Perennial agriculture focuses on crops that remain in the ground year-round, unlike annual crops that are replanted each season.

- This approach is seen as more sustainable and resilient in the face of climate change, as perennial plants have deeper root systems and require fewer inputs.

- Experts argue perennial agriculture can improve soil health, increase biodiversity, and provide more consistent yields over the long term compared to annual crops.

- Perennial crops highlighted include trees, shrubs, and herbaceous plants that produce food, fiber, and other agricultural products.

- Implementing perennial agriculture requires changes to farming practices, infrastructure, and policies to support this transition away from annual monocultures.

- Indigenous communities in particular are highlighted as leaders in developing perennial agricultural systems that work in harmony with local ecosystems.

The article advocates for greater adoption of perennial agriculture as a climate-smart, sustainable alternative to conventional annual crop farming.

items.title: Texas A&M Forest Service breaks ground on new McGregor regional office
items.description: Facility to serve as emergency response training hub and staging area The post Texas A&M Forest Service breaks ground on new McGregor regional office appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M Forest Service is breaking ground on a new $2.1 million, 5,500-square-foot regional office in McGregor, Texas. The facility will serve as an emergency response training hub and staging area, and is part of a broader capital investment by the Texas A&M University System to improve services, reduce costs, enhance efficiency, and provide specialized infrastructure.
