The new office is expected to be completed by the end of 2026 and will reach full operational capacity shortly thereafter. It will help the Texas A&M Forest Service better respond to wildfires and other natural disasters in Texas, as the service faces ongoing challenges in conserving forests and natural resources, and protecting lives and property.

The groundbreaking was attended by Texas A&M Forest Service leadership, Texas A&M University System officials, and local community leaders. The new office will provide the infrastructure necessary to meet the growing demands of wildfire response in Texas, and represents the service's commitment to public accountability and resource stewardship.

items.title: Marion Ag Service Announces the Return of Doug Grott as Chief Operating Officer
items.description: Doug Grott returns to Marion Ag with more than 20 years of experience in agricultural retail and business development. The post Marion Ag Service Announces the Return of Doug Grott as Chief Operating Officer appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Doug Grott has been appointed as the new Chief Operating Officer of Marion Ag Service, a leading agricultural retail company. Grott has over 20 years of experience in the agricultural retail and business development sectors. He previously worked at Marion Ag Service and is now returning to the company in the COO role. No other details on Grott's background or the reasons for his return were provided.

items.title: As carbon pipeline efforts stall, company eyes trucking the gas through North Dakota
items.description: Harvestone Low Carbon Partners is considering transporting CO2 from Dakota Spirit ethanol plant near Jamestown for underground storage.
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Harvestone Low Carbon Partners is exploring trucking carbon dioxide emissions from its Dakota Spirit ethanol plant near Jamestown, North Dakota, about 160 miles west for underground storage.

2. The company requested a $20 million loan from North Dakota's Clean Sustainable Energy Authority (CSEA) in late January for its $95 million project, but the CSEA board voted against providing the funding.

3. Harvestone already operates a carbon storage facility at its Blue Flint ethanol plant near Underwood, North Dakota, where the CO2 has been pumped underground into the Broom Creek Formation since 2023.

4. Transporting CO2 by truck would not be a new practice, but the scale Harvestone is considering is. They plan to capture and store 230,000 metric tons of CO2 annually.

5. Building a pipeline to transport Dakota Spirit's emissions would be expensive, as a 160-mile pipeline would only move about 1,430 metric tons of CO2 per mile, compared to Summit's 2,500-mile pipeline which would move about 7,200 metric tons per mile.

6. Harvestone has an engineering, procurement and construction agreement with Minnesota-based McGough for the project, with a "guaranteed substantial complete" date in January 2027 and full commercial operations planned for later that year.

7. The potential for carbon storage in eastern North Dakota is limited due to the area's geology, so some form of transportation would be needed if companies want to capture, store or use industrial emissions from the region.

items.title: Improving waterhemp control by managing spray water pH
items.summary:
The study conducted in Rochester, Minnesota in 2025 evaluated how spray water pH adjustment and timing of spray solution mixing affected waterhemp control in a corn herbicide program. 

The treatments included a tank mix of atrazine and Acuron GT (at full or half rate) with NIS and AMS, with or without a pH-lowering and buffering adjuvant (AlpHa Shot), and mixed either six days prior to application or at the time of spraying.

Adding the pH-lowering adjuvant reduced spray water pH from 7.5 to 5.8, which improved waterhemp control by 10% at 24 days after treatment (DAT) and 7% at 112 DAT. Waterhemp density decreased by 64% and biomass was reduced by 55% in treatments with the pH adjuster.

The timing of mixing the pH adjuster (6 days ahead or at time of spraying) did not affect waterhemp control, density, or biomass. The improved weed control was observed at both full and half rates of Acuron GT.

The key takeaway is that conditioning the spray water to the proper pH can improve herbicide performance and season-long waterhemp management, regardless of when the solution is mixed. Testing water pH and using a water conditioner or buffering agent is recommended if waterhemp control has been inconsistent.

The study was conducted by Eric Yu and Ryan Miller, UMN Extension Crops Educators, and was published on February 17, 2026 in the UMN Crop News.

items.title: 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February
items.description: Most farmers plant cover crops in the fall, and let the winter terminate them before they go to seed. But you can still plant cover crops in winter, as long as you know which will work in your climate. Plant these five cover crops this month for early spring benefits. The post 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
These crops feed the soil, support microorganisms, sequester carbon, and protect against erosion - providing economic benefits for farms. 

The 5 cover crops recommended to plant in February are:

1. Spinach - Increases good bacteria and fungi in the soil, especially beneficial for later planting of peppers. Requires soil temperature of at least 40¬∞F.

2. Kale - Feeds the soil, people, livestock, and can be a specialty market crop. Needs slightly warmer soil of at least 45¬∞F. Resistant varieties recommended in disease-prone areas.

3. Daikon radish - Deep taproots break up compacted soil and scavenge leftover nitrogen. Requires soil temperature of at least 65¬∞F.

4. Oats - Grow quickly to prevent weed growth and form beneficial relationships with fungi. Can be sown with peas for nitrogen fixing. Tolerate temperatures down to 20¬∞F.

5. Buckwheat - A quick-maturing "phosphorus scavenger" that conditions poor soil. Can be used as a mulch after flowering.

Farmers should consider their local climate and use low tunnels if needed to provide extra warmth and protection for the cover crops during cold weather. Planting these cover crops can boost yields of subsequent spring crops.

items.title: Nature-based toolkit helps Texas communities plan for stormwater management
items.description: New AgriLife Extension resource provides engineers and planners design guidance for natural flood mitigation The post Nature-based toolkit helps Texas communities plan for stormwater management appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service has developed a new resource called the Green Infrastructure for Texas Communities (GIFT) toolkit. This toolkit provides practical, research-based design guidance for nature-based stormwater management solutions to help Texas communities plan for more frequent flooding, rapid development, and aging stormwater systems.

Key points:
- The GIFT toolkit was developed through AgriLife Extension's Disaster Assessment and Recovery (DAR) program, with support from the Texas General Land Office.
- Nature-based infrastructure solutions like rain gardens, bioswales, and permeable surfaces can work alongside traditional infrastructure to slow, capture, and treat stormwater, offering flexibility and additional environmental/social benefits.
- The toolkit is designed for engineers, planners, and local officials to help raise the knowledge base for decision-makers and consultants on how to design and implement these projects.
- The toolkit walks users through the full lifecycle of a project, from site selection to long-term maintenance, and includes technical drawings that can be adapted by local engineers or used when reviewing consultant plans.
- The toolkit is part of DAR's mitigation efforts to reduce the impacts of future storms, building on years of applied research and on-the-ground action along the Texas Gulf Coast.
- While nature-based infrastructure is not a replacement for traditional drainage systems, it is a complementary approach to help communities manage stormwater more strategically.

The goal of this toolkit is to help Texas communities move from discussing stormwater solutions to actually building them, according to Charriss York, AgriLife Extension program leader at DAR.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops! session talked forecasting tools for crop and pest management
items.summary:
The webinar series runs through March and is still open for registration.

Key points:
- Cold weather impacts on overwintering insect pests like soybean aphid, corn rootworm, and alfalfa weevil. Colder temperatures (below 0¬∞F) can lead to 50-95% mortality for some pests.
- Forecasting tools like pheromone traps and degree day calculations can help predict arrival and development of migratory pests like black cutworm, potato leafhopper, and corn earworm.
- Crop disease forecasting tools like the ipmPIPE website track the spread of diseases like southern rust of corn and tar spot.
- The expanding Minnesota Ag Weather Network provides hyperlocal weather data and degree day models for various crops and pests.
- The North Dakota Ag Weather Network (NDAWN) hosts many of these forecasting tools, including models for sugarbeet root maggot, wheat midge, Cercospora leaf spot, white mold, and Fusarium head blight.
- Scouting fields is still important to validate the forecasting tools.

The article emphasizes how these advanced forecasting tools can help Minnesota farmers better time management practices and prepare for crop and pest threats.

items.title: Help the Crops Team fine-tune programming!
items.summary: The University of Minnesota Extension Crops team is seeking input from row crop and forage producers, as well as agriculture professionals who work with producers, to better understand their educational needs and preferences. They are conducting an anonymous 12-15 minute survey to gather this feedback, with the goal of customizing their educational programs to better meet the interests and preferences of the target audience. The survey asks about respondents' operations, learning preferences, and how they want to engage with Extension. The Crops Team aims to use the survey results to refine their programming and make it more useful and relevant for producers. The survey is open until February 16, 2026, and the team encourages all interested parties to participate.

items.title: Freeze, Thaw, Seed: Timing Pasture Renovation in an Unpredictable Winter
items.description: This winter‚Äôs erratic weather, swinging from ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm temperatures in the 50s, has left many wanting spring and ready to get back in the fields. Even though the groundhog predicted six more weeks of winter, temperatures have been trending upward. Over the next week, highs are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night. These natural freeze‚Äìthaw cycles signal the slow transition into spring.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. This winter has seen erratic weather in Iowa, with temperatures swinging from -30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm 50s.
2. Over the next week, temperatures are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night, creating ideal conditions for frost seeding.
3. Frost seeding involves broadcasting or overseeding legumes into a thinning pasture or small grain stand, taking advantage of the freeze-thaw cycle to work the seed into the soil.
4. Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to rejuvenate a declining stand or introduce new legumes, but success depends on timing, soil conditions, and the condition of the existing stand.
5. For more information on best practices for frost seeding, readers are encouraged to review the "Frosting Seeding Legumes" article in the Encyclopedia.
6. The article was written by Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University, who joined the Department of Agronomy in November 2023.

items.title: Frosting Seeding Legumes
items.description: Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, such as red clover, into a tired pasture or within a small grain stand. It is a potentially cost-effective solution to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. Frost seeding is usually not recommended with grass species. The success of frost seeding hinges upon assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, like red clover, into a tired pasture or small grain stand to revitalize the stand in a cost-effective way.

- Timing is critical - frost seeding is typically done between mid-February to early March, coinciding with the freeze-thaw cycle, which helps incorporate the seed into the soil.

- Soil conditions are important - a thick thatch can hinder seed-to-soil contact, so it's recommended to closely hay or overgraze in the fall/winter prior to frost seeding. Sandy soils are less ideal as they don't expand/contract as much during freeze-thaw.

- Adequate spring moisture is vital for establishing a healthy stand after frost seeding. The success of frost seeded stands depends significantly on spring moisture levels.

- The author is Dr. Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist who joined Iowa State University in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems through strategies to enhance resilience and productivity.

items.title: All Day Ag Outlook Conference March 3 at the Beef House

items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Proper protection like greenhouses, cold frames, and low/high tunnels can allow gardeners and farmers to start seeds indoors and transplant them outside later. 

The article recommends 7 vegetables to start from seed in February:

1. Slow-growing herbs like basil and rosemary, which take 1 week to 1 month to germinate.
2. Tomatoes, which need 80+ days from seed to fruit. Opt for determinate varieties in short seasons or indeterminate for year-round harvests.
3. Peppers, which can take up to 1 month to sprout and need 2+ months to mature. Choose productive varieties like jalape√±o, serrano, or shishito.
4. Brassicas like broccoli, cauliflower, and kale, which thrive in cool weather. Leafy types mature quickly, while heading types need more tending.
5. Lettuce, which can handle some late frost and is easy to start directly sown or in trays.
6. Carrots and parsnips, which need to be direct sown due to their sensitive taproots.
7. Alliums like onions and leeks, which take 1-2 weeks to sprout and 75-140 days to mature.

The article notes that February is the right time to start these crops, as they either take a long time to mature, are slow to germinate, or prefer the cool conditions of early spring. Proper growing setups like greenhouses and cold frames can protect these plants until the weather warms.

items.title: Feb 06 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: We had another cold and mostly dry week across the state. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the high 20s in southern Illinois, between 8 and 18 degrees below average. A healthy snowpack in the southern half of the state helped push nighttime low temperatures well below 0, including lows of 7 below in Taylorville and 4 below in Jerseyville. The cold end to January pushed the month as a whole to be around 2 degrees below normal statewide.…
items.summary:
Temperatures this past week were 8-18 degrees below average, ranging from the low teens in northern Illinois to the high 20s in the south. Southern Illinois saw lows of 7 below in Taylorville and 4 below in Jerseyville. January as a whole was around 2 degrees below normal statewide. 

Precipitation was scarce, with most areas getting less than 0.1 inches of light snow. January ended about 2 inches drier than normal statewide, except for parts of Cook and Will Counties which were wetter. While southern Illinois saw nearly 20 inches of snow in January, this only translated to less than 1 inch of liquid water, leaving the region still very dry.

Looking ahead, temperatures are expected to warm up to the 40s and 50s next week, but precipitation will remain limited to less than 0.1 inches. The third week of February is forecasted to be warmer and wetter than average.

The article also discusses the benefits of using the N-Rate Calculator and Precision Conservation Management program to optimize nitrogen application and protect water quality, according to experts John Jones, Gary Schnitkey, and Laura Gentry.

Additionally, the article provides information on WILLAg.org's radio programming, including the Commodity Week and Closing Market Report podcasts.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Farmers are now using AI-assisted tools, voice search, and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without needing to click. The true indicator of content effectiveness is now the time a user spends meaningfully engaged, as this signals real interest and creates stronger opportunities for brand messaging.

AgWeb.com recently underwent a redesign to increase user attention and engagement:
- 54% increase in readers reaching 75% of an article
- 21% increase in readers reaching 90% of an article
- 33% increase in daily article pageviews per mobile user

The article notes that in general, only 16% of users read every word on a page, while 79% scan rather than read fully. Deeper scroll behavior and more articles consumed per visit indicate greater attention and focus.

Attention time is a better indicator than click-through rate, as it measures whether users stayed with the content, scrolled with purpose, and consumed multiple articles - behaviors that directly influence brand recall, message retention, and advertising effectiveness.

The improvements on AgWeb provide a template for increasing engagement and attention, leading to higher quality impressions and better alignment with how farmers search and consume content today. This matters for ag marketers looking to reach farmers in focused, engaged moments.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
The primary goals were to determine if growers can maintain productivity and profitability using reduced tillage and cover crops, and whether starter fertilizer (N+S) could offset early-season challenges in these systems.

The study tested 4 management systems - conventional tillage (CT), fall strip-tillage (ST), no-tillage (NT), and no-tillage with a cereal rye cover crop (NT+CR) - each with 3 starter fertilizer strategies: no starter (UTC), 15 lb N/ac, and 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac. 

Key findings:
- Starter fertilizer increased early-season soybean biomass by ~12% but did not significantly boost yields across any tillage/cover crop system.
- Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across 6 site-years. Yields were similar between CT/ST (78.4 bu/ac) and NT (77.6 bu/ac), with NT+CR slightly lower at 76.2 bu/ac.
- When accounting for operational costs, NT had the highest partial net return, followed by ST and CT. NT+CR had the lowest due to higher cover crop management costs, though these can be offset by cost-share programs.

The project will continue in 2026 to track medium-term soil, residue, and nutrient dynamics under the conservation systems. These findings provide preliminary evidence that soybean productivity can be maintained in reduced tillage and cover crop systems.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
While many farms are on pause due to winter weather, greenhouses provide an opportunity to get a head start on spring crops.

Greenhouses trap thermal heat to warm plants, with some including features like vents, electrical systems, irrigation, and fans for more accurate climate control. Different types of greenhouses are discussed, including modular plastic greenhouses that can raise temperatures 30¬∞F, low tunnels that raise temps 2-15¬∞F, and cold frames that raise temps 5-15¬∞F above outdoor temperatures.

For February greenhouse growing, the article recommends:
- Tomatoes and peppers, which benefit from early indoor planting as their seeds take a long time to emerge
- Brassicas like kale, miniature cabbages, cauliflower, and broccoli raab to get yields before spring
- Lettuces, which can be grown to avoid pests and diseases in frost-free areas
- Potatoes to get full-sized tubers by spring
- Onions of all kinds
- Long-sprouting flowers like lisianthus, coneflower, and dahlias

The article notes that a well-set-up, climate-controlled greenhouse can allow year-round growing of both cool-weather and warm-weather crops.

items.title: Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference
items.description: Kansas City, MO., (January 28, 2026) ‚Äì  The Packer, the produce industry‚Äôs premier publication from Farm Journal, announced the launch of The Avocado Conference, a first-of-its-kind international event gathering every segment of the U.S. avocado supply chain. The inaugural event is set for Nov. 18-20, 2026, at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront. items.summary:
S. avocado supply chain, taking place on November 18-20, 2026 in San Diego, California. - Goals: Collaboration, data-driven insights, strategic industry alignment

The conference is described as a "pivotal moment" that will help strengthen the avocado category amidst high consumer demand, industry innovation, and the need for greater alignment. Attendees will gain indispensable insights and year-round strategic value from the event.

items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators
items.description: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on Jan. 1.
items.summary: The Iowa State University Pesticide Safety Education Program has revised several applicator manuals and exams to reflect the updated pesticide applicator certification and training rules implemented by the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship on January 1, 2026. items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The key points are:

- Lead generation should be about delivering real value to farmers in exchange for their time and attention, not just capturing leads.
- The call-to-action (CTA) and offer you choose are critical, as they shape the quality and purchase-readiness of the leads you generate.
- The mindset should shift from what the business wants to collect, to what farmers genuinely need.
- Designing the right offer that solves real problems for farmers is more important than chasing high lead volumes.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, statistics, dates, names, or expert quotes. The overall recommendation is for businesses targeting farmers to prioritize creating valuable offers over just lead generation tactics.

items.title: Jan 23 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: Winter has come back with a vengeance after a temporary pause. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the mid-20s in southern Illinois, between 4 and 8 degrees below normal statewide. Nighttime low temperatures this week regularly dipped into the single digits, if not below zero, including -5 degrees in Rockford and -2 in Aurora. The wind was also a factor, pushing wind chill values close to -20 on a few days.…
items.summary:
Temperatures this week were 4-8 degrees below normal, with lows regularly dipping into the single digits or below zero, including -5¬∞F in Rockford and -2¬∞F in Aurora. The cold weather was accompanied by strong winds, creating wind chills near -20¬∞F on some days.

Precipitation was also very low, with 7-day totals ranging from around 0.5 inches in northeast Illinois to virtually nothing in southwest Illinois. January to date has been the 4th driest on record in Carbondale and the 10th driest in Charleston, with less than 0.5 inches of total precipitation.

The cold weather is expected to continue for at least another week, with most of the northern half of the state likely remaining below freezing for the rest of the month. However, a strong winter storm is forecast to bring significant snowfall to southern Illinois, with expected totals of 8-12 inches south of Interstate 64, and 3-4 inches in central Illinois.

The article also mentions the WILLAg.org radio programming for the work week ending January 16, 2026, which includes the Commodity Week panel discussion with Chip Nellinger, Brian Stark, and Arlan Suderman, as well as the daily Closing Market Report.

items.title: Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing
items.description: The world is searching for information a bit differently these days. Gone are the days of winning the click (traditional SEO). The game now is centered on winning brand authority and trust (modern AEO, answer engine optimization). In a world now crowded with ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù brands will only cut through by growing brand authority and […] The post Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:
- Farmers are now searching for information differently, moving away from traditional Google searches to using AI-powered platforms like ChatGPT and Google's AI Overviews, as well as mobile voice search.
- To cut through the "AI slop," brands need to focus on building brand authority and trust by providing real, trustworthy information to growers and producers.
- The way farmers find information has fundamentally shifted, and most agricultural marketers are still playing the old SEO game.
- Discoverability is now about ensuring expertise, content, and brand authority surface at the exact moment the audience is looking for answers, across every channel where they are searching.
- In the new AEO era, discoverability is about winning the citation, brand mention, and trusted source reference, rather than just winning the click.

The article suggests that agricultural marketers need to reevaluate their 2026 strategy and adopt an answer-driven content strategy, as well as amplify trusted voices, to remain relevant and visible to their audience.

items.title: Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land
items.description: Also called agroforestry, forest farming is a great way to work within your environmental parameters and utilize the tree canopy to produce more for your farm. Especially for those who live in forested areas, this practice enhances farm output without compromising the ecosystem. The post Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Originating in Brazil's tropical rainforests, this system can work well for farmers with forested areas on their land.

Key points:
- Forest farming combines farming with forestry to create a self-sustaining, ecologically-balanced system. Common methods include thinning forests to grow understory crops, silvopasture (combining forestry and ranching), and alley cropping.
- Benefits include improved soil/water quality, carbon sequestration, habitat for beneficial species, and the ability to grow specialized forest crops like mushrooms, ramps, and syrups.
- Ideal lands for forest farming have existing forests or riparian areas with trees that can be managed.
- Farmers should inventory their resources, develop a forest management plan, and research niche forest products that can be grown and marketed.
- Regulations around wild-harvested plants need to be considered.

Overall, forest farming can be an economically and environmentally beneficial way for farmers with forested land to diversify their operations.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
Key points include:

Objectives: Spray drones can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce field traffic, and improve access to hard-to-reach areas. Farmers should clearly define their specific goals before investing.

Regulations: Operators must have an FAA Part 107 Remote Pilot Certificate and Part 137 Certification for aerial pesticide application. State-level IDALS licensing is also required. Rules change frequently, so checking for updates is important.

Insurance: Standard farm policies don't cover aerial application risks. Farmers need chemical, general, and physical damage liability coverage specific to drone operations.

Equipment: Factors to consider include spray capacity, battery life, nozzle options, and GPS/automation features. Local dealer support is also key.

Training: Proper training on safe operation, calibration, and weather monitoring is essential. Iowa State offers educational programs on compliance and best practices.

Adoption Approach: Farmers are encouraged to start small, compare results to conventional methods, and gradually scale up as they gain experience. Dry product applications can also be evaluated cautiously.

Resources: Iowa State University, the Digital Ag Innovation Lab, licensed dealers, and IDALS can all provide support for farmers new to spray drone technology.

The article highlights that spray drones can be a valuable addition, but successful integration requires careful planning and a thoughtful, stepwise approach. Staying up-to-date on regulations, safety, and best practices is crucial.

items.title: The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow
items.description: For farms in colder areas, starting seeds in time for the spring market requires a significant amount of time and indoor space. Winter sowing is a method that can be done outdoors and gives seedlings a stronger constitution as they mature. Here, we share plants that thrive when winter sown. The post The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Winter sowing involves starting seeds in containers like milk jugs or plastic bags and placing them outdoors, where the cold, moist conditions help the seeds break dormancy. This results in hardier transplants that mature sooner than they would otherwise.

The best vegetables for winter sowing include hardy greens like kale and cabbage, as well as spinach, onions, and leafy greens like chard and watercress. These plants can handle cold temperatures in their early stages.

For flowers, the article recommends sowing perennials like pansies, echinacea, snapdragons, larkspur, and scabiosa. Many of these need a period of cold stratification, which the winter sowing method provides.

Specific varieties mentioned include 'Carex' cabbage for shorter maturation, 'Avon' spinach for mildew resistance, and different groups of snapdragons suited to varying light and heat conditions.

The article notes that winter sowing offers the benefits of direct sowing with less risk, and provides a natural way to break dormancy for plants that require cold stratification. It's an excellent method for farmers looking to get a head start on the growing season.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.
items.summary:
The 2026 Crop Advantage Series meetings will be held at 12 locations across Iowa from January 6-29. The meetings are organized by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach to provide farmers and crop production professionals with the latest research-based information to help them make informed decisions for the upcoming growing season.

The meetings will feature topics tailored to local growing conditions and challenges, including crop market and climate outlooks for 2026, nitrates and drinking water, profitable nutrient management, southern rust, transition planning, and robots and drones.

Early-bird registration is $75 until the week before each meeting, and late or on-site registration is $100. The registration fee includes refreshments, lunch, certified crop advisor credits, and access to resources. Private pesticide applicator recertification will also be available at each location for a separate fee of $30.

The meeting locations and dates are:
- Jan. 6 ‚Äì Sioux Center
- Jan. 7 ‚Äì Storm Lake
- Jan. 8 ‚Äì Burlington
- Jan. 9 ‚Äì Mason City
- Jan. 13 ‚Äì Estherville
- Jan. 15 ‚Äì Waterloo
- Jan. 16 ‚Äì Davenport
- Jan. 21 ‚Äì Ankeny
- Jan. 22 ‚Äì Atlantic
- Jan. 27 ‚Äì Iowa City
- Jan. 28 ‚Äì Le Mars
- Jan. 29 ‚Äì Carroll

According to Josh Michel, a field agronomist with ISU Extension and Outreach, the goal of the meetings is to "prepare producers to manage potential issues when they arise, or even before they arise, by sharing the most up-to-date scientific knowledge from Iowa State University researchers."

items.title: Purdue field day to feature research on sorghum‚Äôs value as a forage crop
items.description: Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on Sept. 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center (FPAC) in Bedford, Indiana.
items.summary:
Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on September 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center in Bedford, Indiana. Interested participants should register by September 5.

The event will feature research on sorghum's value as a forage crop. Sorghum is more drought-tolerant and has lower nitrogen requirements compared to corn, and does not host the tar spot pathogen. Experts will discuss sorghum's production and utilization for silage, grazing, and as a standing winter feed source.

Attendees will learn about forage sorghum research from Mitch Tuinstra, Wickersham Chair of Excellence in Agricultural Research and scientific director of the Institute for Plant Sciences at Purdue. He will share plant breeding techniques to improve sorghum yield and quality. Other speakers include Brad Shelton, Jason Tower, Nick Minton, and Jeff Jackson.

Venue tours will be available from 3-5 pm and 6-8 pm, and a dinner and bull test station tour will be offered from 5-6 pm.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. Responses to the individual questi
items.summary:
The Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113 in July 2024, indicating improved farmer sentiment despite declines in corn and soybean prices. The Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations rose 7 points to 119.

Key statistics:
- Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5% for corn and soybeans, respectively, from mid-June to mid-July.
- 34% of farmers cited high input costs as their biggest concern, and 29% cited the risk of lower crop and livestock prices.
- The Farm Financial Performance Index dropped 4 points in July to 81, 6 points lower than in July 2023.
- The Farm Capital Investment Index rose 6 points in July to 38, though it remains 7 points lower than in July 2023.
- The Short-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index rose to 118 from 115 in June, while the Long-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index dropped 6 points to 146.
- 72% of crop farmer respondents expect cash rental rates to remain roughly the same as in 2024, with the remaining respondents nearly evenly divided between expecting an increase or a decline.

The survey was conducted from July 15-19, 2024. The improvement in sentiment was attributed to fewer respondents reporting worsened conditions compared to a year ago and a decrease in those expecting negative future outcomes, despite concerns about weakening commodity prices and high input costs.

items.title: Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn
items.description: For more than a century, tar spot fungal disease in corn kept its distance from the U.S., biding its time
items.summary:
Purdue researchers are adopting an interdisciplinary approach to assess the emerging tar spot disease in corn. The research team, led by C.D. Cruz, associate professor of botany and plant pathology, is using a mix of statistical, data science, epidemiology, microbiology, artificial intelligence, and computer vision methods to understand the dynamics of tar spot in corn.

The research is funded by two grants totaling nearly $1.1 million from the USDA National Institute of Food and Agriculture. The team is collaborating with researchers from Colombia, Mexico, Ecuador, South Korea, and the U.S.

The researchers have developed a digital method called the stromata contouring detection algorithm (SCDA) to quantify tar spot in corn. They have tested the algorithm under field conditions and found it to be successful in quantifying trends, but some inaccuracies persist in fully automated scenarios. The team is now refining their training methods to improve the model's accuracy and performance.

Another research effort includes the laboratory of Purdue's Mohammad Jahanshahi, associate professor in the Lyles School of Civil and Construction Engineering and the Elmore Family School of Electrical and Computer Engineering. Jahanshahi and Cruz, along with their students, are working on a proof-of-concept data fusion project that integrates drone imagery and weather data to capture crucial details about the tar spot pathosystem.

The researchers aim to quantify and model tar spot epidemics in production-style fields using disease observations and drone-based imagery. Ultimately, the team wants to quantify and model tar spot severity by referencing and integrating imagery with spatial and temporal data.

The interdisciplinary nature of the project can place greater time demands on the researchers, but it also leads to better problem-solving as each person brings their own expertise to the table.

items.title: ISA will host sheep-themed educational opportunities and competitions at Indiana State Fair
items.description: In addition to 4-H and open sheep shows, the Indiana Sheep Association (ISA) is sponsoring sheep-themed competitions, vendors and educational opportunities at this year‚Äôs Indiana State Fair, with additional support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN SW).
items.summary:
The Indiana Sheep Association (ISA), with support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN S&W), is hosting various sheep-themed events and competitions at the 2024 Indiana State Fair:

- The Wool and Ewe Room and Ewe2 boutique will be open throughout the fair, offering wool items, livestock-themed apparel, and more.
- On August 2 at 10 a.m., there will be an open wool judging and wool sale event in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion.
- The Make It With Wool (MIWW) competition and fashion show will take place on August 4 at 2 p.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.
- The Indiana State Fair Shearing Contest will be held on August 4 at 5 p.m. in the Ball State University Champions Pavilion.
- From August 8-11, 11 a.m.-6 p.m., the Taste from Indiana Farms event in the Indiana Farm Bureau Fall Creek Pavilion will offer free samples of Indiana lamb.
- The annual Sheep to Shawl competition, where youth teams create a wool shawl from scratch, will be on August 18 at 10 a.m. in the Indiana Arts Building.
- Sheep will be exhibited in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion for open and 4-H shows from August 4-20.

ISA President Jane Smith stated that the association is "proud to bring the spirit of our industry to the fair, and this year we will bring it in the theme of 'Art and Nature,' showcasing sheep-related art from Indiana artists in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion."

items.title: Purdue Extension to present engaging art and nature demonstrations at Indiana State Fair
items.description: The Indiana State Fair kicks off Aug. 2 and highlights the theme ‚ÄúThe Art Nature of Fun‚Äù in collaboration with Newfields. Fairgoers will have the opportunity to speak with Purdue University representatives about agricultural and nature-related topics, which are available year-round through Purdue Extension.

Other Purdue events include:

Purdue University is a public research institution ranked among the top 10 public universities in the U.S., with a focus on affordability, accessibility, and the pursuit of new innovations.

items.title: Potassium Cycle now available!
items.description: Check out the new NPM publication! This two-page publication gives a visual overview of the potassium cycle as it relates to general Wisconsin cropping systems, and on the second page, outlines some key potassium concepts …
items.summary:
The new NPM publication "Potassium Cycle" provides a comprehensive visual overview of the potassium cycle in Wisconsin cropping systems. The two-page publication outlines key potassium concepts, including:

- Sources of potassium, including soil minerals, organic matter, and fertilizers
- Potassium uptake by plants and movement within the plant
- Potassium losses from the soil through leaching, crop removal, and erosion
- Recommended potassium application rates and timing for optimum crop yields

The publication was developed by the University of Wisconsin-Madison to help farmers better understand the potassium cycle and make informed decisions about potassium management in their operations. It is available for free download on the NPM website.

items.title: Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update
items.description: Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, University of Wisconsin-Madison Winter wheat in Wisconsin continues to move through growth stages at record pace. We are about 10-14 days …
items.summary:
Wisconsin winter wheat is progressing at a record pace, about 10-14 days ahead of normal. As of April 17, 2022, 26% of the winter wheat crop was in the jointing stage, compared to the 5-year average of 10%. Wheat condition is rated 79% good-to-excellent, higher than the 5-year average of 71%.

Experts Damon Smith and Shawn Conley from the University of Wisconsin-Madison recommend that farmers monitor their wheat closely for disease and insect pressure as the crop advances rapidly. They advise applying fungicides at flag leaf emergence to protect against Fusarium head blight and other diseases.

The early wheat development is due to warmer than average temperatures in March and April. This accelerated growth could lead to earlier wheat harvest, potentially impacting management of other summer crops. Farmers should adjust plans accordingly and be prepared to shift fieldwork schedules as needed.

items.title: Questions to consider prior to replanting a soybean field
items.description: Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist, UW-Madison Early in the growing season, abiotic (freezing temperatures, hail, flooding, etc.) and biotic (slugs, deer, disease, insects, etc.) factors often reduce soybean plant stands. A soybean …
items.summary:
Soybean fields may need replanting due to factors like freezing, hail, flooding, pests, and diseases. Before replanting, farmers should consider:

1. Yield potential - Replanted soybeans may yield 5-10% less than the original stand. Yield loss is higher for replanting beyond June 1st.

2. Maturity - Replanted soybeans will be 7-10 days later to maturity. This can impact harvest timing and drying costs.

3. Weed control - Replanting provides a chance to change herbicide programs and manage weeds more effectively.

4. Seed quality - Germination and vigor of replacement seed should be checked. Seed treatments may be needed.

5. Planting date - Ideal replanting dates are before June 1st in northern climates. Yields drop significantly for plantings after June 15th.

6. Stand uniformity - Uneven stands can impact harvestability and yield. Aim for a uniform 100,000-150,000 plants/acre.

Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist at UW-Madison, recommends carefully evaluating these factors before deciding to replant a soybean field.

items.title: Spraying 2,4-D on Soybean in 2024?
items.description: Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager, UW-Madison Division of Extension, Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist, UW-Madison Are you planning to spray 2,4-D for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybean? The 2,4-D …
items.summary:
Key points:
- Farmers planning to use 2,4-D on Enlist E3 soybean in 2024 need to be aware of important updates and restrictions.
- The use of 2,4-D on Enlist E3 soybean will be prohibited in 2024 due to regulatory changes.
- Farmers should instead consider alternative weed control options for Enlist E3 soybean in 2024, such as glufosinate and clethodim herbicides.
- Rodrigo Werle, a Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist at UW-Madison, advises farmers to stay informed about the latest updates and plan their weed management strategies accordingly.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, statistics, or percentages. It also does not mention any deadlines, names of people/organizations/programs, or locations beyond UW-Madison. The context is the regulatory changes affecting the use of 2,4-D on Enlist E3 soybean in 2024. The main impact for farmers is the need to adjust their weed control plans for Enlist E3 soybean next year. The article recommends that farmers consider alternative herbicide options and stay informed about the latest updates.

items.summary:
